title.narrative: Improving the living conditions of Internally Displaced Persons in Chamakor and Hasansham U3 camps.

description.narrative:
Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) living in the camps are exposed to extreme weather conditions which can reach 50°C during the hottest months of summer. IDPs in Chamakor and Hasansham U3 camps live in tents with no connection to electricity for home use, including cooling. The most affected group are women, children, older persons and persons with disabilities who have to stay at home/in the tents during the day. Provision of electricity to these camps is therefore a critical and lifesaving priority during the summer.
To meet this need, UNHCR plans to establish electricity networks powered by generators in each of Chamakor and Hasansham U3 camps. These networks will provide electricity to power street lights, as well as to provide electricity at each tent in the camps which will enable the beneficiaries run water coolers. UNHCR will establish the electricity network, provide generators, and cover fuel costs for six months. The expected result is that each displaced family in the camp will have access to up to 3 amperes of electricity in their tents, for an estimated 10 hours per day. Streetlights throughout the camp will also be powered by the project.
The provision of electricity at the tent level will coincide with distribution of small air coolers by the government. It is expected that this intervention will alleviate the extreme heat in tents, which has been identified as a key push factor motivating premature returns to areas in and around Mosul. At the same time, the availability of electricity in tents will reduce the risk of fire by providing safe options for lighting. Charging phones will be easier, facilitating communication with family members that may support family reunification, collection of information prior to return, and arrangements for sponsorship. Street lights will also serve to reduce the risk for Gender Based Violence (GBV) and petty crime by ensuring adequate lighting throughout the camps at night.
